path_1.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_1.feeling: Electrifying tension and obsession left me exhilarated and uneasy.

path_1.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_1.feeling: Gritty craftsmanship and friendship made the racing stakes genuinely thrilling.

path_1.title: Shrek (2001)
path_1.feeling: Clever and fun, though its broad humor didn't fully land for me.

path_1.title: Piper (2016)
path_1.feeling: Tender, wordless storytelling that warmed me and wowed me in minutes.

path_1.title: Book Thief, The (2013)
path_1.feeling: Poignant and humane, if a bit polished, it still moved me.

path_1.title: Secretary (2002)
path_1.feeling: Offbeat intimacy and character growth intrigued me more than the kink.

path_1.title: The Gambler (2014)
path_1.feeling: Compulsively watchable self-destruction, but kept me at an emotional distance.

path_1.title: Apollo 11 (2019)
path_1.feeling: Purely cinematic history that stirred awe without needing narration.

path_1.title: Blue Jasmine (2013)
path_1.feeling: A sharp, unsettling character spiral that lingered with me.

path_1.title: Alien (1979)
path_1.feeling: Atmospheric and tense, but the sci‑fi horror kept me at arm’s length.

path_1.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_1.feeling: Lean, gripping conspiracy thrills with satisfying moral stakes.

path_1.title: Palmeras en la nieve (2015)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping, emotional and immersive—this one stayed with me.

path_1.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_1.feeling: Clever and tight, though more mental puzzle than emotional punch.

path_1.title: The Girl on the Train (2016)
path_1.feeling: Engaging mystery with mood and momentum, if not profound.

path_1.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_1.feeling: Visceral, anti‑war grit with complex characters—powerful stuff.

path_1.title: Bolt (2008)
path_1.feeling: Cute and energetic, but lightweight for my taste.

path_1.title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016)
path_1.feeling: Conviction and courage made the brutality meaningful and affecting.

path_1.title: Counselor, The (2013)
path_1.feeling: Stylish but chilly

path_1.title: Sherlock Holmes (2009)
path_1.feeling: Lively and witty, though the action glossed over depth.

path_1.title: Breach (2007)
path_1.feeling: Tense, grounded spy drama that hooked me on character dynamics.

path_1.title: Narvik (2022)
path_1.feeling: Wintry, small‑scale WWII stakes that felt authentic and engaging.

path_1.title: Judge, The (2014)
path_1.feeling: Formulaic at times, but the father‑son turmoil resonated.

path_1.title: Avatar (2009)
path_1.feeling: Grand spectacle with thin characters

path_1.title: Man on Wire (2008)
path_1.feeling: Joyful, nerve‑jangling celebration of audacity and craft.

path_1.title: Insider, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Riveting moral battle that had me locked in start to finish.

path_1.title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)
path_1.feeling: Some imaginative world‑building, but flat characters and overblown set pieces.

path_1.title: Tell No One (Ne le dis à personne) (2006)
path_1.feeling: Twisty, propulsive and satisfying without cheapness.

path_1.title: Stoker (2013)
path_1.feeling: Elegant, eerie mood piece that quietly burrowed under my skin.

path_1.title: Secret in Their Eyes, The (El secreto de sus ojos) (2009)
path_1.feeling: Rich, haunting blend of mystery, memory and longing.

path_1.title: Snowden’s Great Escape (2015)
path_1.feeling: Clear, tense account that sharpened the ethical stakes.

path_2.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_2.feeling: Ferocious and focused, the cost of greatness left me breathless and unsettled.

path_2.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_2.feeling: Rousing and meticulous, the craft and clash of egos hit my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Shrek (2001)
path_2.feeling: Witty and warm, fun but less affecting than my usual fare.

path_2.title: Piper (2016)
path_2.feeling: Gorgeous and wordless, a tiny tale that hit surprisingly hard.

path_2.title: Book Thief, The (2013)
path_2.feeling: Tender and earnest, touching though a bit softened for my taste.

path_2.title: Secretary (2002)
path_2.feeling: Odd and intimate, its power dynamics intrigued me more than they shocked.

path_2.title: The Gambler (2014)
path_2.feeling: Stylish but detached, its self-destruction kept me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Apollo 11 (2019)
path_2.feeling: Immersive and awe-inspiring, pure archival craft that thrilled me.

path_2.title: Blue Jasmine (2013)
path_2.feeling: Sharp and uneasy, a brittle character study that lingered.

path_2.title: Alien (1979)
path_2.feeling: Tense and atmospheric, impressive even if the horror left me less moved.

path_2.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_2.feeling: Lean and gripping, corruption and conscience in a satisfying cat-and-mouse.

path_2.title: Palmeras en la nieve (2015)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping and emotional, its love and history swept me away.

path_2.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Clever and claustrophobic, its looping dread worked on me.

path_2.title: The Girl on the Train (2016)
path_2.feeling: Moody and engaging, twisty even if not top-tier.

path_2.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_2.feeling: Gritty and uncompromising, its anti-heroic war view hit hard.

path_2.title: Bolt (2008)
path_2.feeling: Cute and brisk, charming but light for me.

path_2.title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016)
path_2.feeling: Sincere and intense, conviction carries it through the carnage.

path_2.title: Counselor, The (2013)
path_2.feeling: Bleak and stylish, its nihilism fascinated more than satisfied.

path_2.title: Sherlock Holmes (2009)
path_2.feeling: Zippy and fun, the flash entertains even if it feels shallow.

path_2.title: Breach (2007)
path_2.feeling: Quietly tense and credible, the slow-burn duplicity hooked me.

path_2.title: Narvik (2022)
path_2.feeling: Stark and earnest, a lesser-known theater rendered gripping.

path_2.title: Judge, The (2014)
path_2.feeling: Glossy and heartfelt, the family-courtroom blend worked enough.

path_2.title: Avatar (2009)
path_2.feeling: Visually grand, emotionally familiar—impressed more than moved.

path_2.title: Man on Wire (2008)
path_2.feeling: Playful and exhilarating, a true caper that left me grinning.

path_2.title: Insider, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Meticulous and gripping, a whistleblower saga that tightened my chest.

path_2.title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)
path_2.feeling: Slick spectacle, but the stiffness and clutter left me cold.

path_2.title: Tell No One (Ne le dis à personne) (2006)
path_2.feeling: Propulsive and emotional, a twisting man-on-the-run that gripped me.

path_2.title: Stoker (2013)
path_2.feeling: Elegant and eerie, its perverse undercurrents unsettled me.

path_2.title: Secret in Their Eyes, The (El secreto de sus ojos) (2009)
path_2.feeling: Elegant and poignant, its long echoes of justice and love hit hard.

path_2.title: Snowden’s Great Escape (2015)
path_2.feeling: Absorbing and tense, the escape logistics and stakes fascinated me.

path_2.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_2.feeling: Ferocious and precise, its obsessive mentorship had me clenched and exhilarated.

path_2.title: Ford v. Ferrari (2019)
path_2.feeling: Rousing and meticulous, the craft and corporate tug-of-war satisfied me.

path_2.title: Shrek (2001)
path_2.feeling: Witty and playful, enjoyable but not a personal favorite.

path_2.title: Piper (2016)
path_2.feeling: Tiny but sublime, its wordless courage warmed me.

path_2.title: Book Thief, The (2013)
path_2.feeling: Tender and earnest, moving in moments but gentler than I crave from WWII stories.

path_2.title: Secretary (2002)
path_2.feeling: Offbeat and intimate, its thorny power dynamics felt oddly compassionate.

path_2.title: The Gambler (2014)
path_2.feeling: Stylish and self-destructive, intriguing more than affecting for me.

path_2.title: Apollo 11 (2019)
path_2.feeling: Majestic and methodical, pure archival awe that left me hushed.

path_2.title: Blue Jasmine (2013)
path_2.feeling: A sharply observed unraveling that left a lingering ache.

path_2.title: Alien (1979)
path_2.feeling: Atmospheric and nerve-tightening, admired more than loved.

path_2.title: Absolute Power (1997)
path_2.feeling: Lean and gripping, its corruption-and-coverup cat-and-mouse hit my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Palmeras en la nieve (2015)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping and emotive, its cross-generational romance swept me away.

path_2.title: Timecrimes (Cronocrímenes, Los) (2007)
path_2.feeling: Clever and claustrophobic, its looping dread satisfied my puzzle itch.

path_2.title: The Girl on the Train (2016)
path_2.feeling: Engaging and twisty, effective even if it didn't cut too deep.

path_2.title: Cross of Iron (1977)
path_2.feeling: Bleak and visceral, a morally scathing war portrait that gripped me.

path_2.title: Bolt (2008)
path_2.feeling: Cute and brisk, pleasant but light for my tastes.

path_2.title: Hacksaw Ridge (2016)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and intense, conviction carried me through the brutality.

path_2.title: Counselor, The (2013)
path_2.feeling: Icy and nihilistic, left me more frustrated than gripped.

path_2.title: Sherlock Holmes (2009)
path_2.feeling: Spry and witty, a fun romp that skimmed rather than sunk in.

path_2.title: Breach (2007)

path_2.title: Narvik (2022)
path_2.feeling: Sturdy and sobering, a perspective I valued more than I was devastated.

path_3.feeling: Engaged by the craft, camaraderie, and corporate friction.

path_3.feeling: Amused by the playful twists, even if the fairy-tale sheen kept me a bit detached.

path_5.title: Breach (2007)
path_5.feeling: Low-key spy drama with moral tension I appreciate.

path_5.title: Narvik (2022)
path_5.feeling: Wintry, boots-on-the-ground WWII tale that hits my history-and-duty buttons.

path_5.feeling: Solid courtroom-family drama with satisfying emotional beats.

path_5.title: Avatar (2009)
path_5.feeling: Visually dazzling, narratively familiar—engaging but not a favorite.

path_5.title: Man on Wire (2008)
path_5.feeling: Graceful, gripping doc about obsession and audacity.

path_5.feeling: Riveting whistleblower drama with ethical weight I’m drawn to.

path_5.feeling: Spectacle-heavy and flat in character stakes for my taste.
